importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The research voyage to the Gascoyne Marine Park took place in late 2022, marking the key timeline for the discovery of new marine species.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The discoveries from the 2022 expedition are still being analyzed and published, with estimates suggesting 600 more species may be described in the coming years.

keyTakeAways: A semi-transparent crab, about the size of an almond, was discovered at a depth of approximately 122 meters in the Gascoyne Marine Park, Western Australia.

A new species of lantern shark, the West Australian Lantern Shark, was found over 600 meters below sea level, growing up to 40cm and exhibiting bioluminescence through photophores on its belly and flanks.
The porcelain crab discovered is about 1.5cm in length and uses long hairs to filter feed on plankton instead of using claws to catch food.
The discoveries were made during a research voyage by CSIRO scientists in the Gascoyne Marine Park, 20km off the coast of Western Australia.
Australia is a global biodiversity hotspot with over a million species, many of which remain unexplored due to deep-sea inaccessibility.

About 20 new species have been formally described from the 2022 expedition, with scientists estimating that around 600 more species remain to be described and named due to the lengthy process of verification and classification.

namedEntities.name: Australia
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A country in Oceania, one of the world's major biodiversity hotspots.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Australia is home to unique and many endemic species, making it a key region for deep-sea biodiversity discoveries.

namedEntities.name: Gascoyne Marine Park
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A marine protected area located about 20km off the coast of Western Australia.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The research voyage to the Gascoyne Marine Park led to the discovery of multiple new marine species, highlighting the unexplored potential of this region.

namedEntities.name: CSIRO
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Australia's national science agency responsible for scientific research and innovation.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: CSIRO scientists conducted the deep-sea exploration that resulted in the discovery of new species, demonstrating the role of national science agencies in biodiversity research.

namedEntities.name: West Australian Lantern Shark
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A newly discovered species of lantern shark found over 600 meters below sea level.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This species exhibits bioluminescence and is one of the key findings of the deep-sea exploration, contributing to understanding of deep-sea adaptations.

namedEntities.name: Porcelain Crab
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A new type of porcelain crab, about 1.5cm in length, found at 122 meters below sea level.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The discovery illustrates a unique feeding mechanism, using hairs to filter plankton, which differs from typical crab behavior.

namedEntities.name: Carnavon Flapjack Octopus
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A newly described species of octopus, approximately 4cm in size and colored rust-red.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is one of the 20 species identified from the 2022 expedition, adding to the diversity of marine life found in the deep sea.

namedEntities.name: Dr Will White
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A fish scientist involved in the research.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Dr White provided scientific explanation for the bioluminescent properties of lantern sharks, enhancing public understanding of the species.

namedEntities.name: Dr Andrew Hosie
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Curator of aquatic zoology at the Western Australian Museum.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Dr Hosie explained the feeding mechanism of the porcelain crab, contributing to the scientific accuracy of the article.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Australian scientists from CSIRO discovered two new marine species during a 2022 deep-sea expedition in the Gascoyne Marine Park, off the coast of Western Australia. A semi-transparent porcelain crab, about 1.5cm long, was found at 122 meters depth, using hairs to filter feed on plankton, while a new lantern shark species, the West Australian Lantern Shark, was discovered over 600 meters below sea level with a glowing belly. These findings highlight the rich, unexplored biodiversity of Australiaâ€™s deep-sea regions, a global biodiversity hotspot. So far, 20 new species have been formally described, with scientists estimating up to 600 more to be identified in the future due to the lengthy process required to verify species uniqueness.
title: Australia: Almond-sized crab and tiny lantern shark discovered in deep seas
